title: 114_hr3691
content: The Act titled "Improving Treatment for Pregnant and Postpartum Women Act of 2016" reauthorizes residential treatment programs for pregnant and postpartum women under the Public Health Service Act. Additionally, it establishes a pilot program for grants to state substance abuse agencies. The Act "Improving Treatment for Pregnant and Postpartum Women Act of 2016" establishes a pilot program for state substance abuse agencies to provide competitive grants for family-based services for pregnant and postpartum women with substance use disorders. The pilot program aims to address gaps in services for pregnant and postpartum women with substance use disorders, promote a coordinated state system managed by substance abuse agencies, and require agencies to submit applications for grants. The Director must identify eligible State substance abuse agencies for grants under the program, which support family-based treatment for pregnant and postpartum women with substance use disorders. Grant recipients are not required to provide services only to women in facilities or offer all services described in subsection (d). The Director must specify a minimum set of services for eligible women under the pilot program, based on recommendations and services described in subsection (d). Considerations may be made to not apply certain requirements to applicants depending on circumstances. The Director will convene stakeholders to recommend a minimum set of services for a pilot program lasting up to 5 years. An evaluation will be conducted at the end of the first grant cycle. The Director of the Center for Behavioral Health Statistics and Quality, in coordination with the Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Treatment, will submit a report to relevant committees on the outcomes of the pilot program, including reductions in drug use, engagement in treatment services, retention in services, access to FDA-approved medications, and other measures. The term 'State substance abuse agency' refers to the agency managing the Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Block Grant. Funding for carrying out subsection (r) is limited to 25% of the total amount available for the year under this section. No funds can be allocated to subsection (r) unless sufficient funds are available for the overall section. The amount available for fiscal year 2016 under this section must not exceed the amount available for the current fiscal year. SEC. 4. CUT-GO COMPLIANCE. Amends subsection (f) of section 319D of the Public Health Service Act to allocate specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2016, 2017, and 2018. Passed by the House of Representatives on May 11, 2016.
